PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: why are Australia's long-term real interest rates, as measured by 10-year bond rates, now at their highest level in more than 30 years? What effect will this have on Australian business? Did not the government learn any lessons from the worst recession in 60 years?

—One hopes that, as rats in a maze learn their way out after a period of time, even Senator Hill would learn some of the basic realities about the setting of long-term interest rates, which are not within the control of the Australian monetary authorities or the Australian government. They are set by the market and they have regard—or they should have regard—to the underlying fundamentals of the economy. Manifestly at the moment they are not. Manifestly they are having regard more to overseas developments and perceptions as to interest rates that seem likely to prevail and economic activity that seems likely to prevail elsewhere rather than to the underlying reality of the Australian scene and the predictions that all reputable analysts and economists are making.

PARA.TAB: To be building in—as these figures seem to—inflationary expectations of five or six per cent simply is against the run of all the objective analysis that is coming from commentators here within the system. The fundamentals just do not give rise to interest rates of that particular kind and there is no basis for those sorts of figures. So we just have to live with the reality of that figure being struck. But it has nothing to do with the government's deliberate decision making in the area of interest rate management; nor has it anything to do, as I keep saying, with the underlying fundamentals of the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the government's policy is to deliberately force up interest rates in order to dampen demand as an alternative to tackling the deficit, is it not therefore surprising that long-term real interest rates are so high? I ask: what effect does the minister think this will have on Australian business? As I said, has not the lesson of the last recession been learnt, because in the run up to that recession what the minister was saying to us was exactly the same thing—it was the market and it was not government policy.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Every other country has a deficit; doesn't it worry you that you are basing your question on a wrong assumption?

—I am indebted to Senator McMullan for that interjection because he was making the very obvious point that those opposite are talking about the Australian balance of payments situation and the budget deficit as being somehow a contributor to this; and yet every other country to whom he is drawing attention by way of comparison to Australia has a much higher deficit than we have in terms of the current account situation.

PARA.TAB: There is no rational relationship between long-term interest rates as they are prevailing now and the present condition of the management of the Australian economy, because the underlying realities of the Australian economy are that we have—as is constantly being said—the best conjunction of fundamentals for 30-odd years. The growth rate is fine. The inflation rate is fine. The level of investment that we are currently experiencing is fine. The wages situation is fine. There is no basis for these sorts of assumptions. Whatever has happened in the past in relation to short-term interest rates bears no rational relationship to the long-term situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Over the past week there has been a great deal in the press regarding APEC-related activities in Jakarta. I understand that, whilst it has not been reported widely, during the minister's recent visit to Jakarta for the APEC ministerial meeting, a trade and investment agreement was signed with Mexico. Could he advise the Senate as to what this agreement will mean for Australian export, for investment and for jobs?

—I thank Senator Forshaw for raising this issue, which has been underestimated. This agreement with Mexico represents a major step forward in the commercial relationship between Australia and Mexico. It is the sort of international agreement that generates significant benefits for Australia and is the sort of international negotiation in the trade area that needs to be undertaken. Those who think we should in some way be withdrawing from international agreements fail to see the potential benefit these agreements can generate.

PARA.TAB: This is an agreement which positions Australia to capture some of the benefits of the predicted rapid growth in the Mexican market. It provides practical benefit to Australian exporters and investors in two ways. There is a framework for the resolution of trading problems that might emerge between the two countries as our level of economic engagement increases. We both have relatively open economies but that does not mean no conflicts can arise. For example, Australian beef exports to the Mexican market have dropped dramatically as a result of the imposition in 1992 of a 25 per cent tariff on frozen beef. Of course, our competitors in the US and Canada do not face that because of NAFTA. There is also a complex issue, which I will not take up the time of the Senate with now, about our relationship with Mexico concerning sugar. Overall, we have a very positive relationship and a basis on which we can build.

This agreement provides an opportunity to examine and develop new opportunities for trade and particularly for investment, because Mexico is becoming a country of major commercial opportunity for Australia and more and more countries are showing interest in it. This is the third aspect of this agreement. It has a demonstration effect. It says to Australian business, `This is a country to which you should be giving more attention. Here are some significant opportunities.'

Mexico is an economy in which there has been dramatic economic reform. It is a country of 90 million people and with a GDP growth of 3.8 per cent. As it opens, so an increasing proportion of its economy is being serviced by imports. Our exports to Mexico have tripled over the past four years, but they are still very low. They are now $192 million, although, as I said, that is a tripling in the last four years. It has risen to be significant amongst our markets around the world, although it is still nowhere near the top of the list and nowhere near its potential, particularly on the investment side, where Australian businesses are just starting to look. We are getting some mining investment there. But even though exports are picking up, we are underperforming on the investment side.

I look for this agreement to be one of those aspects that will increase the priority in that, as is the decision—the very welcome and correct decision—by the department and by my predecessor to include Mexico as a focus market at the national trade and investment outlook conference. It is another demonstration effect raising the significance of this market in the eyes of Australian business, both for trade and investment, and is also a very practical way of making contacts for Australian business in Mexico and for allowing Mexicans to make contact in Australia.

We are also developing much more of a habit of dialogue and cooperation with Mexico as it comes into APEC and as it has now joined the OECD. This trade and investment agreement is significant directly for our trade and investment relationship with this increasingly important and underestimated economy. It is also a signpost of the way into the growing Latin American market, an area with one of the fastest rates of growth in the world and with significant political change going on, generating further significant opportunities. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of the total inability of the Leader of the Government in the Senate to answer Senator Hill's very simple question asking why Australia's long-term interest rates now under this government are at their highest level in over 30 years, let me try another interest rate question on one of his junior colleagues. I ask it in the context of the OECD having recently predicted that Australia will have the highest long-term interest rates of any of its members in 1995. Is he aware that bank, housing and business loans are now around nine per cent and rising? Is it not also a fact that real interest rates are above seven per cent and rising? Why are real interest rates so much higher than current and projected rates of inflation? Can he assure the Senate that interest rates on home loans will not rise over the next six months?

—If Senator Short had actually listened to the answer provided to Senator Hill by Senator Gareth Evans a moment ago instead of interjecting at the top of his voice, he would have heard a quite clear and cogent explanation. The main feature of the explanation was Senator Evans accurately reporting that, of course, we do not regulate long-term bond rates in Australia. That is a feature of market activity, and as far as those in the long-term bond market factoring in inflation rises of the order in which they apparently are—between six and seven per cent—are concerned, there is no empirical evidence, nor is there any evidence among the economic pundits or the government forecasts, that such a level of inflation in Australia is at all likely or indeed tenable.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, it does leave a question as to why they do this, and do it in a speculative market. I must say I am somewhat surprised but, nonetheless, they do do it and it is a factor of the market—it is not a factor of government regulation. So the opposition cannot come to us as a government and say, `In this area that you don't regulate, you are responsible for the way in which speculators go about setting long-term bond rates.'

Interest rates in Australia tend to be higher than the inflation rate, and that has been a long-term feature of the economy. I have often heard senators from the other side compare Australia with New Zealand and, on the basis that a conservative government applies in New Zealand, therefore New Zealand somehow or other attracts their admiration in preference to their own country. It is my understanding that interest rates in New Zealand are higher than interest rates in Australia and that that is a feature of its economy. This is an empty and vacuous question which has already been answered in the main by Senator Evans. I have nothing further to add.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I point out to the minister that since January this year Australia has experienced a rise of 65 per cent in long-term interest rates—the sharpest rise ever recorded, and a rise double that experienced by the United States over the same period. In view of the minister's complete failure to answer my first question, I ask: is the minister saying that, with his government's appalling track record on forecasting and on delivering economic results, the Australian community should believe his government's view on the nature of interest rates as opposed to the well-informed market's view?

—It is very interesting that Senator Short should raise the question of our forecasting ability. I recall vividly that shortly after the budget was brought down, Senator Short joined in the chorus of other sceptics in Australia, arguing that the budget forecast on investment projections—a 14 1/2 per cent growth in investment for the budgetary year 1994-95—was impossible to achieve, or was unbelievable, and went on to rubbish the forecasts, as oppositions always do, to try to undermine the budget settings. But, of course, we are now seeing that we may have been in fact wrong in the sense that we may have underestimated the growth in investment in this country, because the figures that are coming through now—and given the latest predictions of the agency that Senator Short prefers to cite, Access Economics—show that our estimates are in fact realistic. Therefore, the opposition cannot have the allegation that it now makes. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer to the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, which comes into effect tomorrow. I understand that the convention will effectively double the coverage of Australia's territory, adding almost 15 million square kilometres of marine territory to our exclusive economic zone. I ask the minister: what implications does this convention have for our marine based industries and research institutions? What obligations or challenges does the acquisition have with respect to understanding and management of the oceans surrounding Australia and its territories?

—I thank Senator Neal for this question because it is important. Tomorrow, 16 November, the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea comes into force, and the area of territory controlled by Australia will increase by 150 per cent as a consequence. The Convention on the Law of the Sea ensures that Australia can lay claim to territory 200 nautical miles from its coastline or to the edge of the continental shelf, whichever is the greater. That means that the area under Australian control will increase by 14.8 million square kilometres of ocean. This is a vast increase in the amount of responsible area in the world controlled by this country, and it imposes on us a huge responsibility. We will have sole rights of control and sole rights to exploit the living and non-living resources in this extra area.

PARA.TAB: The government has already put in place the necessary legislation earlier this year to define and create the exclusive economic zone, as it is called, and other marine zones to which we are entitled under the Convention on the Law of the Sea. Our new maritime claim includes the seas surrounding Australia, the Antarctic and other territories out to 200 nautical miles or approximately 370 kilometres.

Under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, Australia also has sole right to seabed mineral resources on the sections of our continental shelf which extend beyond the 200 nautical mile EEZ. Our combined exclusive economic zone and continental shelf claims under the United Nations convention add up to 14.8 million square kilometres, which is close to twice the area of the Australian continent and is probably the largest ocean claim worldwide under this United Nations convention.

The United Nations convention effectively confers ownership to Australia on the resources in this exclusive economic zone and also allows us to host a host of other rights, including control over scientific research, cable laying and the erection of offshore structures. But the United Nations convention also demands that we manage this exclusive economic zone in a sustainable way to ensure that the living resources in it are not destroyed, depleted or irreparably harmed. The future economic and social benefits of our new offshore claims are almost certainly massive, but this is only an educated guess as there is still a small amount of knowledge about what the features are in terms of fisheries, oils, mineralisation, gas and other resources which may exist in this massive ocean perimeter.

I can say, for example, that CSIRO predicts that by the year 2015 the farming of tuna fish in this area of ocean controlled by Australia will be worth more than the total value of the beef industry in Australia in terms of exports. The marine research will be essential for Australia to get a baseline study in place and work out how sustainably we can tap the huge potential of this area. The research we need to undertake is to be developed and conducted in close cooperation with industry environmental groups in the community, which ultimately own this area and will benefit or lose depending on how we manage it.

We know less about this area than we already know about the surface of the planet Venus, so there is a huge amount of work to be done in getting the baseline scientific studies correct. I am pleased to say that steps are being taken to do that and a major conference on this subject will be held in Canberra tomorrow. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, concerns the damage to World Heritage values occurring at Oyster Point in Cardwell, North Queensland. I ask the minister: what does he propose to do about the destruction of mangroves occurring at Oyster Point? Has he received advice from his department about the World Heritage values of the area and how they will be affected? If he has received that, what is the nature of that advice? Has he raised the matter with the Queensland government? And, most importantly, is he preparing to proclaim the Hinchinbrook Channel under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act?

—Mr President, I share Senator Kernot's concern about the mangrove clearing that is taking place in the Hinchinbrook Channel adjacent to the Port Hinchinbrook development. Since the clearing was first proposed and the deed of agreement for the development was drawn up, information has been made available to me and my department that gives us cause for grave concern about the likely impacts of the clearing on the seagrass communities that are adjacent to the site in the channel. These seagrasses are feeding grounds for dugong and are an integral part of the World Heritage values of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area.

PARA.TAB: I have asked my department to assess the available information and I have received its advice. The advice is not unequivocal, given the limited amount of scientific information that is available. It concludes that there is an urgent need to halt the clearing until a full scientific assessment can be made.

Accordingly, this morning I spoke to my Queensland counterpart, Ms Molly Robson, and to the Premier of Queensland, Mr Goss, informing them of my department's advice and urging them to take immediate action to halt the clearing. I have made available to them the information on which I based that particular request. I can also say to Senator Kernot that this morning I spoke in similar terms to the developer, Mr Williams.

My intention, once the clearing has been halted, is to convene a workshop of experts to obtain a consensus of opinion on the impacts on seagrass beds. I am currently awaiting a response from the Queensland government.

As to the final part of the question, which went to the issue of the proclamation of the area under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, I can only say that I have that option under consideration. Clearly, that would be a last resort which I would exercise only after the other options are exhausted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. However, how long will it take to work through these other options? I am sure the minister would be aware that yesterday, in just one day, bulldozers cleared between one-third and one-half of the old growth mangroves. What is the time frame? The minister must know that if he waits long enough it will be too late.

—I do appreciate the urgency in relation to this issue and I do appreciate the fact that we need to act urgently. I can assure Senator Kernot that my department and I are giving this matter the highest possible priority.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask the minister: is the Australian government aware of the escalation in the conflict in south-eastern Turkey between the Turkish military and the Kurdistan Workers Party? Is the Australian government concerned about the effect this is having on the civilian population in the area, particularly given recent reports of the burning of villages and the forced relocation of civilians by the Turkish security forces? If so, will the government express its concern and make representations to the Turkish government?

—It is very difficult to obtain objective reporting on the situation in south-eastern Turkey, which is effectively a war zone. The government is, however, concerned about reports of escalation of violence in that area and of high casualty figures among the civilian population, together with the reports of the burning of villages and the forced evacuation of civilians in the region, with each side in the dispute blaming the other for these acts.

PARA.TAB: There have been conflicting reports about the burning of villages. There are reports that the military has been burning villages to deny the Kurdistan Workers Party, the PKK, food and shelter. There are also reports that the PKK is burning villages to dissuade villages from cooperating with the Turkish government.

We have already urged the Turkish government on a number of occasions to exercise restraint in dealing with the insurrection in south-east Turkey and have encouraged a peaceful solution to the problem. At the same time, we recognise the real threat that PKK action does place on Turkish internal security.

The Australian Embassy in Ankara has raised a number of reported cases of human rights abuse with the Turkish government. Where these reports have been verified, we have made representations seeking guarantees that the human rights of individuals are observed. These representations reflect Australia's support for the universal application, as always, of internationally accepted standards of human rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the response?
—There was a reasonable response at governmental level.
—We're always hearing that you have raised these things, but we never hear the response.

—I would like to see how effective you would be, Elmer, when you were vested with any sort of responsibility for anything. The Australian government has unreservedly condemned both atrocities committed by the Turkish military and acts of terrorism committed by the PKK. We urge the Turkish government again to distinguish between separatist militants and Kurds who are simply not involved in the fighting.

PARA.TAB: We have also expressed our strong views on the desirability of recognition and protection of the rights of Kurds within Turkey and elsewhere in the region. We will continue to monitor the situation in south-east Turkey and will continue to urge, as I am saying, the government to exercise restraint in its fight against terrorism and to encourage peace in the region.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister should be aware that the most devastating drought effects that we now have in rural New South Wales and Queensland will not wait for his dithering over the development of a comprehensive policy. The groundwater supply is fast running out, stock feed is running out and 40 per cent of the beef herd will be gone by autumn. Given the government's limited and inadequate assistance to date, does it have a comprehensive plan to face this current drought crisis if there is no rain by Christmas, if there is no rain by February 1995 and if there is no season breaking rain in time for planting cereal crops in April 1995? If the government has developed comprehensive plans to assist rural farm and business units to survive the worst drought on record, could the minister please tell the Senate what they are?

—The government announced a drought assistance package which was widely welcomed by farm organisations across Australia in as strong terms, I might add, as the coalition's drought policy was comprehensively rejected on the same day that it was released. Senator Tierney, who has developed a sudden interest in drought for the first time in his political career—it is certainly the first time he has raised this in the Senate—would perhaps be more useful if he would direct his input on that issue to those on his own side, who have in fact so far not contributed anything useful to this debate at all. I have indicated on previous occasions that I am—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. That is an outrageous slur and an imputation against a very hardworking and genuine senator. I ask that you ask Senator Collins to withdraw that. It is also completely contrary to the facts.
—I took it as part of the debate, but I would ask you, Senator, to answer the question rather than attack the opposition.

—What the government has been doing, and doing effectively, is to provide a progressive response to what is regrettably a progressively deteriorating situation. As I advised the Senate the other day, and I can advise Senator Tierney now, despite the fact that the government's scheme has been operating now for only a bare four weeks—and I checked again this morning—applications for assistance under the scheme have now exceeded 4,000 and well over 2,000 payments have now been approved. They are being processed at the rate of around 200 a day, and the current approval rate is in excess of 90 per cent.

PARA.TAB: I also advised the Senate—Senator Tierney was clearly asleep when I was doing so—that I would have discussions with my state colleagues, all of whom, I might add, supported this move, to develop a more scientifically based set of criteria upon which exceptional circumstances could be based. One of the difficulties in Australia at the moment is that the drought declarations are state government matters and the processes by which they are carried out differs widely from state to state. Indeed, a number of states have no drought declaration processes at all, which means that it is crucial to get a more uniform national response to this.

Some significant progress was made on this at the ARMCANZ meeting recently held in Adelaide. I have been advised by the New South Wales minister for agriculture, Mr Causley, that an application will now be made from New South Wales for additional exceptional circumstances assistance, and I expect to receive that shortly. When I do receive it, it will be referred to the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council, chaired by Neil Inall, in the same way as other applications for exceptional circumstances are.

In respect to the two points that Senator Tierney made about what would be without question a horror scenario of the drought not even breaking, on current predictions of the Meteorological Bureau, in autumn next year, I have repeatedly stated the situation that would be involved then. The government's current proposals in fact are nationally applied and will progressively extend if the drought does extend.

The facts are, however—and I have said this before—that if the drought should not break by autumn of next year, if we do not get a substantial relief in what will then be the fifth continuous year of drought for areas of Queensland in particular, it will at that point have escalated to a major domestic crisis, not just for the rural community but for the whole Australian community. There is no question that the government at that point will have to examine the responses that will then be necessary, because the quantums of assistance that will then be required will be extremely high indeed. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister must have been the one asleep when I was asking the question, because I did not ask him a question about the welfare measures. I asked him a question about what he was doing to help support the rural farm and business units. Out in rural Australia the whole rural infrastructure and economy are now facing collapse because of his lack of assistance to the business units. So let me repeat that aspect of the question. Has the minister developed any comprehensive plans to assist rural farm and business units—let me repeat it: rural farm and business units—to survive the worst drought on record? Could he please tell the Senate what they are? Given the minister's answer, which obviously indicates a lack of clear plans, would we be right in viewing his management of drought policy as about as effective as his management of pay TV policy in this country?

—If Senator Tierney likes to look at the policy success of that particular enterprise, I would be happy to have that comparison made. I recall, for example, Senator Alston predicting that we would not get $30 million for the licences, so if I were Senator Tierney, I would not stand too firmly on that. The facts are that in close cooperation with the major peak primary industry bodies in Australia we have produced a policy in respect of handling this drought. I might say it is a distinctly different approach from that of the opposition. I am taking a further package of measures to cabinet. I have announced that about 50 times before now.
—Four years—it's taken you four years to do nothing!

—I presume Senator Tierney would have provided $600 million on day one. That is an idiot interjection. I was about to conclude by making the point that this submission to cabinet has also been put together very carefully in close consultation with those same peak farming organisations.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. It refers to her letter in the Australian on 4 November 1994 in which she asserted that critics of the government's family tax policy, quoted in Kate Legge's article, do not want genuine choice. If, as the minister states constantly, child care is a cost of earning income, why is it not also a cost for a one-income family in which one spouse cannot engage in paid work if the other does not care for the children? Why is one spouse not allowed to deduct for tax purposes, payments to the other spouse to care for the children whilst he or she does paid work? Where is the genuine choice when the fringe benefits tax exemption for child care excludes the care of a child in its own home by a parent?

—The thrust of Senator Harradine's question, as I understand it, concerns the different treatments for the payments for child care in the home, as opposed to payments for child care in formal child care arrangements. Quite clearly, there are ways in which this government has addressed those needs. The decision to assist with the cost of child care through child-care assistance, as Senator Harradine well knows, deals with the needs of low income families but the additional introduction of the child-care cash rebate this year goes to the recognition of two things.

PARA.TAB: The first is that child care is a legitimate cost against earning an income and, like any other cost against earning an income, it is non-income tested. Unlike other tax deductions, it is paid as a rebate to enable the costs of child care to be offset as they occur. Properly, like any other tax rebate, it is not income tested and recognises the cost of child care as a legitimate claim against income. The second thing it does is extend the assistance for the cost of child care to the informal sector. Up until now, we have not been able to really assist with the informal costs of child care; yet we know how many families use informal child care either by choice or by necessity.

The other thing Senator Harradine's question does not recognise is that many of the people accessing our child care are effectively in single-income families or are not in the work force. This figure is not recognised. Our program tries to balance most of all keeping the costs of child care fair and, at the same time, making the provision of child care available to as many people as possible. For example, our occasional child care and the fee relief—the child-care assistance for that—is never mentioned by Mrs Carole Carroll, Senator Minchin or anybody opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not paid at the same level.

—It is paid at exactly the same level. I find it very interesting that Senator Newman does not want to acknowledge that. What we have done is recognise the need for child care and recognise through the tax system assistance for child care and, at the same time, with the payment of the home child-care allowance, recognise the importance of a continuing income to the spouse at home caring for children and the invaluable work that that person does in caring for children.

PARA.TAB: I believe that what we have done is recognise those changing roles of women in particular. In their adult lives they will move from the care of children at home, particularly when the children are young, to participation in the work force, and they have a need for child care to assist them in doing that. We have provided programs that support them in their choice. We have used direct payments through child-care assistance and have now assisted that with the tax program for the child-care cash rebate. It is a program that extends child-care assistance to as many families as possible. I believe it is very much based on access and equity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Try again.

—Yes, I will try again. I do recognise all of those matters, but that was not my question. In fact, I recognised and based my question on what the minister actually said—that child care is a legitimate cost of earning income. I asked the minister: if that is the case, why is one spouse not allowed to deduct for tax purposes payments to the other spouse to care for the children while he or she goes to work? Where is the genuine—
—Can you claim the cost of ironing your clothes at home?

—Excuse me; I wonder whether the minister would mind if I spoke. Where is the genuine choice when the fringe benefits tax exemption for child care excludes the care of a child in its own home by a parent? That is what I am asking the minister. My question goes to the issue of equity.

—This is a strange re-run by Senator Harradine of an argument that he put very extensively during the debate on the home child-care allowance and, indeed, the introduction of the child-care cash rebate. There are, first of all, basically no outlays for the cost of the child care provided in the home as compared with the cost of child care outside of the home.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen to those opposite! There are no reductions in the family income outlays. If opposition senators want to argue that there is not a difference, I suggest they might like to ponder on what their howling at that point means. There is no comparable example in any other of the tax systems for the transfer of costs within the family itself.

PARA.TAB: I suppose the honourable senator can propose this hypothetical about why should not he, if he goes to work, be able to claim a tax deduction for the cost of the child care his wife is providing for him. It would be a stunning exception to every other example of how the tax system works on family income. I think it is important to recognise that child care provided within the family is not an outlay on that family income.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. While acknowledging the overall benefits to Australian industry from the Uruguay resolution, I point out that there are some Australian industries, like the egg and pork industries, that receive no assistance but in the follow-on from the GATT implementation will go to a total free market and be placed in an unfair trade position compared with other countries which will continue to benefit from high assistance levels. For example, the Canadian egg industry will go from a 192 per cent tariff to a 164 per cent tariff, which is equivalent to 80c a dozen over the next six years. As other countries have introduced measures to ease industries through their adjustments to the new GATT requirements, such as an $86 billion package to Japanese farmers and the US proposals, what does the government intend to do for these particular unassisted Australian industries that will be left totally exposed to a continuing unfair international trade situation, including imports from countries which will retain high subsidy levels?

—The reason that Australia has taken such a major initiative through the Cairns Group in seeking to create a climate of fair trade in agriculture is that that is overwhelmingly in the interests of the Australian economy and the Australian rural sector. We have been out in front. The essence of Senator Boswell's question is that we did not, in the Uruguay Round, get as far as we would have wished in getting the elimination of distortions and unfair subsidies in the agricultural industries, and that is correct. We made more progress than has ever been made before. I realise Senator Boswell acknowledged that, and I thank him for that because it is unusual. This is the first time in which the Australian agricultural sector has made big gains out of such negotiations, and this is fundamentally because of the initiatives taken by my predecessors through the Cairns Group, with the support of a large number of other countries.

PARA.TAB: One of the interesting examples that Senator Boswell gave—I did not get a chance to note them all, but I tried to take them down as he spoke—was the subsidy for the Japanese rice farmers because of the wonderful achievement that we gained in getting access to the Japanese rice market, even though it was less than we should have had. They are having to pay subsidies to compensate for the fact that Australian farmers, for the first time, will get access to this market. The last figures that I saw estimated this market to be worth more than $100 million a year to Australian rice farmers.

We are trying to open up the market. We are continuing around the world—through multilateral, bilateral and, most immediately, regional activities—to create opportunities for Australian agricultural, manufacturing and service providers to get better market access. But we do not have the budget to compete with the subsidies provided by the major players. If we sought to enter into a subsidy contest, we would lose. It would be against our interest, and it is certainly not consistent with the policy of reducing the budget deficit by slashing outlays, which Senator Boswell's party proposes. We cannot increase spending on everything and reduce outlays at the same time.

We cannot enter, and hope to win, the subsidies war. What we can hope to do is get effective constraints upon those subsidies, which we have done through GATT, put pressure to remove non-tariff barriers, put downward pressure on tariffs, which we have gained and continue to campaign for through the Cairns Group, through bilateral approaches, such as those I mentioned earlier with regard to Mexico, and through regional activities, such as APEC, but not only APEC. Those are the strategies we intend to propose.

With regard to some industries of which Senator Boswell would be aware—for example, the dairy, tobacco and citrus industries—the government is looking at packages of assistance, because the measures taken during the GATT round had a direct impact on those industries. We will be announcing the details of those quite soon.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Trade. It follows on from the question that was asked by Senator Boswell, except I wish to direct my question more into the future and refer to the government's negotiations regarding APEC. I refer to the fact that the government has said that it will not exempt high employment industries, such as the TCF and car industries, from the requirement of zero tariffs. Is this not a lousy deal, seeing that we have reports in the media that, under APEC, the government will not get any further concessions in the agricultural area? Other nations, in fact, will not be prepared to open their markets to our farmers. What will we gain from the APEC meeting? What will the government do to get us a better deal?

—The difficulty in answering this question—and I understand the genuineness with which it is asked—is that both of the assumptions on which it is based are wrong. I know of no indication whatever that agriculture will not be included in the APEC meeting. I have spent two days talking about APEC with representatives of the 17 other countries. None of them raised it. Maybe somebody else knows more about it than any of us, but it was not raised at the ministerial meeting and has not been. I am not aware of that proposal. In the course of negotiations, it may be that someone will seek to raise that. If so, we will deal with it when it arises. But it has not arisen yet.

PARA.TAB: I am also not aware of any representative of the government saying that we will necessarily require zero tariffs on the TCF and motor vehicle industries. Exactly how the liberalisation will be implemented—if it is achieved today, and I very much hope it is—will take some time to work out. Australian business will be very closely consulted. I had some initial discussions with representatives from the motor vehicle industry this morning when they visited me on another matter. We commenced very early discussions—talks about talks, I suppose they could be called.

We are committed to providing policy certainty for industry. As honourable senators know, there are already proposals in place for reviews concerning TCF and passenger motor vehicles to look at the post-2000 arrangements. Those reviews will need to take into account what other countries are doing about trade liberalisation in APEC and what is happening about the opening of other markets to them.

Our motor vehicle industry is one of the least protected in the region. If we were to get common strategies of very low protection for motor vehicles in this region, it would be of enormous benefit to our industry, which is seeking to export into Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and around the area and which is having difficulty getting into those areas because there are tariffs of somewhere between 100 per cent and 300 per cent. It is still getting some exports because it is an efficient industry, but it is not getting as much as we would like. That is the strategy that will lead to a strong industry—not trying to continue to build a strong industry on the back of a market of 17 million people.

Similarly, our TCF industry, which is exporting strongly and the exports of which have gone up significantly in recent years, would find exporting much easier if it faced lower tariff barriers in APEC. I have grave doubts about the assumptions that underlie the question, but that is, as best I can give it, a picture of how we will be handling it.

We will be influenced in any tariff reductions we make by the pace of tariff liberalisation by our trading partners. Unlike some in previous times, we have not been prepared to commit Australia to zero tariffs across the board before there was any talk of trade liberalisation within APEC. We will make decisions based on our judgment of our domestic interest. We will continue with the existing program of liberalisation because we think it is in our interests. We will do other things over and above that as we assess developments within APEC.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to the 10 woodchip export licences that are coming up for renewal. Can the minister indicate to the Senate how many jobs and what export revenues are dependent on these licences?

—My role as minister for the environment in relation to this round of woodchip export licence renewals is, as a result of a cabinet decision that was made at the end of last year, to advise the Minister for Resources on the applicability of the national forest policy statement to that licence renewal round. I might say, Mr President, that it is a responsibility that I have taken very seriously indeed.

PARA.TAB: I have indicated on many occasions—perhaps Senator Kemp has been too busy shouting and interjecting to catch up with this—that I am very keen indeed to progress the conservation goals of the national forest policy statement. Senators would be aware that the NFPS has been a significant attempt to bring about a balance between conservation and industry interests in the forest debate. It is my responsibility—

TALK.START.PARA: —Answer the question.
—I am talking about my responsibilities as the environment minister. Just because Senator Kemp is too much of a dope to be able to direct the question to the relevant minister—
—Order! That sort of language is really not helpful.
—Is truth no defence, Mr President?
—I just think it is inappropriate language.

—If it is inappropriate, I withdraw it. It would have been far more appropriate for Senator Kemp to direct his question on the employment aspects of the export woodchip renewal round to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. What I am able to do in my role as environment minister—a responsibility that I intend to take very seriously right through this particular process—as well as giving the statutory advice supplied by the Australian Heritage Commission under section 30 of its act to the Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall, is to give him very thorough advice with real integrity about the conservation elements and the applicability of the NFPS to the woodchip licence renewal round.

PARA.TAB: I remind honourable senators that one of those conservation objectives I have spoken about is the so-called moratorium clause on areas of old growth and wilderness likely to have high conservation value. There is also the commitment contained within the national forest policy statement that goes to the question of the need for us to have established on public land by the end of 1995 a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system. Those are my responsibilities. They are responsibilities I am treating seriously.

I intend to ensure that the advice that I give Mr Beddall has the benefit of my portfolio agencies acting in a very coordinated way. To that end I have involved the Australian Heritage Commission, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, the new forest branch within the environment strategies directive which I have established since I have been minister, the EPA and a number of other mechanisms to ensure that the advice given on my responsibilities in relation to export woodchip licences is thorough, stands up and certainly represents those responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. We have now seen a minister stand up in response to a very straightforward question—and this is a minister of the Labor Party—about how many jobs will be affected by the actions he takes. He had four minutes to answer that question. He could not give us an answer and basically does not care how many jobs his particular actions affect. I put it to the minister: can he assure the Senate and the people employed in this industry that he will not give any advice which will jeopardise the massive employment in this sector?

—I can assure the Senate that I am taking my responsibilities as environment minister very seriously. I tried to explain to Senator Kemp what those responsibilities were. I can assure him that the government is sensitive to issues such as employment in this particular industry. To that end, for example, I am the only environment minister who has convened a working group of trade unions who represent the forestry industry and conservation organisations. That is an indication of the sort of significance I give that particular issue. But I really do think that someone who pretends to be a frontbench representative in this chamber ought to be intelligent enough—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The issue is relevance. It was a straightforward question. Senator Faulkner has convened all these working groups; he should tell us how many jobs are at stake. That is the question to which we want an answer.
—That is not a point of order. I judge the answer to be relevant. Do you wish to complete your answer, Senator Faulkner?
—It is difficult to try to indicate to someone as thick as Senator Kemp what my responsibilities are.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, would you withdraw that. It is not helpful.
—All right. I have tried to indicate to Senator Kemp—
—Mr President—
—Senator Macdonald, are you raising a point of order?
—No, the minister's time finished about 30 seconds ago. I am standing for the next question.
—I call Senator Murphy. Senator Alston on a point of order: you are raising a point of order—you do not have the call.

—Yes Mr President, I am raising a point of order: I think it is important that this chamber does accord respect to the chair. You have just had a very offhand and sleazy display of defiance of the chair.

—I know you cannot accept the umpire's decision. For Senator Faulkner to say, `Oh, all right' in such a dismissive way is a calculated insult to the chair, and you ought to tell him that it is not acceptable.

—Mr President, on the point of order: this point of order comes from someone who was named in this chamber by a chairman of committees and refused to withdraw. So he should not lecture this chamber on disrespect for the chair.
—If you invite me to withdraw, Mr President, I do withdraw.
—I call Senator Murphy.
—Mr President, on a point of order: I was standing when the minister finished his answer. Was it not appropriate for you to call me when no-one else was standing?

—Mr President, on a point of order: points of order were awaiting rulings when Senator Ian Macdonald stood to get the next call. You deal with that and then you call someone on their feet. If those opposite do not want to go along with the normal rotation of questions, let them say so and put forward an alternative proposal.

—Order! Senator Robert Ray is, of course, right and it is also true that we do have an agreed rotation. The next question was coming from the government side, and it is quite clear. I call Senator Murphy.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. It is now some six months or so since the government responded to the independent review of the Australian Customs Service, or the Conroy report, as it has become known. What information is the minister able to provide regarding the implementation of the report's recommendations which the government accepted? Is the minister able to provide the Senate with an assurance that at the end of the process Australia will actually have a better Customs Service?

—Yes, it is now over six months since the government accepted the overwhelming recommendations of the Conroy review into the Australian Customs Service. Since then, the government has got on with the job of carrying out those recommendations. I am able to say to the Senate and to those senators interested in this issue—and there has been plenty of interest in the restructuring of Customs over the last 12 months—that, for example, we have appointed a new head of Customs and we have established a Customs Advisory Board on which the private sector has the majority of positions.

PARA.TAB: This week 319 officers will be retiring from Customs under a voluntary redundancy program. A further 67 officers will be retiring early next year and, in accordance with the agreement of cabinet and after discussions with the staff and with the union, there will be new recruitment coming into Customs to provide new blood into the system, but there will be around 250 overall reductions in positions in the Customs Service in line with the reform process. This is a significant saving to the operation of Customs and, of course, a significant saving to the budget of the Australian government.

Not only have we established a new Customs Advisory Board; we have also established new industry panels, including an industry panel on gateway clearance which also will deal with mandatory electronic clearance. After discussions with industry, if we are able to proceed with these new processes, we will find that this is an area that will provide further substantial savings in the future; but it will only be done after direct consultation with both the staff and with industry.

A second industry panel has been established on Customs audit reforms, again looking at ways in which maybe self-assessment in this area can provide substantial savings and more efficiency for the private sector in the area of auditing. We also have a close relationship with the Customs National Consultative Committee. Where appropriate, it has now been agreed that that body will be consulted on the introduction of any legislation for Customs which does not affect budget procedures but which would have an obvious impact on the industry.

So all in all there have been significant changes in the structure of Customs. I have to say there are now very encouraging signs that with the full support of the staff—and I want to emphasise with the full support of the staff—the culture of Customs, which many senators complained about over 12 months ago and earlier this year, is now changing and that change is well under way.

Though we still have a long way to go, I want to pay tribute to the overwhelming majority of Customs staff who have accepted the need for change in the operation and management of their own service. They realise in the long run they will end up with a better service offering a better career structure—a structure that will offer them a more encouraging lifetime career if they choose to stay within the service. So the changes in the last six months have been significant. We have not completed the changes, but they are well under way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, yesterday Senator Ellison asked me a question about the imprisonment of Australian businessman Eric Robert Bowra in the United Arab Emirates. I undertook to supply some further information when that came to hand. I now do so.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday I confirmed to the Senate that on 13 November Mr Eric Robert Bowra, an Australian businessman from Western Australia, was sentenced by a UAE court to a prison term of 12 months. This term is to take account of the time Mr Bowra has already served. In addition to the prison term, Mr Bowra was ordered to pay to the family of the deceased the equivalent of about $A55,000 as compensation. This amount has been paid from funds lodged with the court.

The embassy in Riyadh has now provided me with a translation of the judgment. The judgment, in Arabic, was given to the Australian consul who attended the hearing on 13 November. In the judgment Mr Bowra was found guilty on three counts: manslaughter, causing injury and not aiding the injured. The court, in deciding on the criminal aspects, left it open to the family of the injured party to pursue civil compensation including property damage claims.

Mr Bowra was not present for the hearing. On the other hand, it seems though that the family of the injured party or its legal representative were also not present. Mr Bowra's legal representative from the legal firm of Aljabri and Partners, Abu Dhabi, did not object to the hearing proceeding without Mr Bowra being present. I am informed that both Mr Bowra's legal adviser and an independent legal source considered that this course, though unusual, was not illegal. I believe Mr Bowra's business associates and his legal adviser have decided to appeal the sentence and will do so within the prescribed period of two weeks. It is expected that hearings in regard to the appeal could commence in early December.

There have been questions raised about the matter of Mr Bowra's release, or application for release, on bail. On 5 October a departmental officer in Abu Dhabi, that is one of my officers, was told by Mr Bowra's business associates and legal adviser that they were considering their options regarding the bail order, which had been made on 27 September and was unsuccessfully appealed against by the prosecutor the following day, 28 September.

An embassy officer was advised on 24 October by Mr Bowra's legal adviser that the lawful reason for the continued detention of Bowra was not known. The next day the embassy official submitted a formal request to the UAE authorities for an explanation regarding Mr Bowra's continued detention. The Australian ambassador in Riyadh followed this up with a high level inquiry on 2 November. A further follow-up was made by the Australian consul to the head of the consular department of the UAE foreign ministry on 12 November, but this was then overtaken by the events of 13 November. Our embassy in Riyadh has, nonetheless, been instructed to seek a written response to its representations, and I will advise Senator Ellison when further information comes to hand.

An important question, and one that I touched on yesterday, is whether an Australian citizen has received, as we would expect, the benefit of the same laws, administration and protection of rights and redress that are available to citizens of the country in which the arrest took place. Mr Bowra's legal adviser has told the Australian consul that a UAE national would have been treated in the same way as Mr Bowra. While his business associates have concerns about the judgment against their colleague, there has been no suggestion that—apart from the bail question which remains unresolved, and we are awaiting answers on that—he has been treated otherwise than in accordance with UAE law.

In these circumstances, apart from the issue relating to bail, there is evidently no role for the Australian government in the judicial processes of the United Arab Emirates. The next step would seem to be Mr Bowra's appeal, and that is solely a matter for his lawyers. Australian consular officials will, nonetheless, continue to monitor Mr Bowra's wellbeing. I seek leave to have the judgment incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: Basis for the sentence in the criminal case no.: 1344/94 legal misdemeanour

The public prosecution presented Eric Robert Bowra after the naval collision accident between the boat of the defendant and the victim's boat. When Jeffrey Howard was questioned, he said that he was with the defendant in the boat and that the cause of the accident was a collision between the two boats and that the defendant was driving his boat quickly, turning and returning and that he knows no explanation for the incident.
When the victim's son, Khaled Ibrahim, was questioned, he said that the boat of the defendant came in a fast manner and collided with their boat.

When Suheil Freih Al-Qabees was questioned, he said that he saw the boat of the defendant going very fast and turning around spectacularly and then heading forward again. When the boat of the victim was coming, the boat of the defendant collided with it strongly from the left side. Due to the strength of the collision, their boat flew up in the air about 10 meters. The report of the criminal laboratory no: 1120/2/14 proved that the iron boat collided with Al-Danah which belongs to the victim at its front left half and went over it by an angle of 45 degree towards the rear right side, colliding with the external edge of the driving cabin.

When the defendant was questioned, he admitted his error in front of police. But he said to the public prosecution that it was not his fault and that it was the victim's fault. When he was confronted with his attempt to leave the country and his arrest at Abu Dhabi airport, he admitted this and said that he attempted to leave because of fear after the incident had taken place. He explained his inability to treat the victim by saying that there had been other people with him in the boat who were injured as a result of the accident and that he had intended to treat them, and that the incident was near the beach.
The defendant paid the blood money and 50,000 dirham for the value of the victim's boat.

The court session of 25 October 1994 was attended by the defendant and the victim's son, as one of the heirs. A representative of the heirs also attended. The son of the victim insisted that the defendant had failed to help them and had left after the accident. The representative of the heirs said that the heirs accuse the defendant of murder because he did not treat the victim after the accident, and this being evidence that the defendant acted deliberately. The representative of the heirs requested that the case be referred to the public prosecution to investigate the defendant and also requested that the second victim be referred to a medical committee.

Regarding the request of the heirs' representative to refer the case to the public prosecution to investigate the defendant on the crime of murdering the victim, the court rejected this request because it is clear from the papers of the case that the incident took place by mistake. It is clear from the testimony of the witness Suheil Freih Al-Qeesy that the defendant was wandering about the sea and performing spectacular moves. This was before the arrival of the victim and the accused did not change his behaviour. The two sides were surprised to be face to face. If it was deliberate, the boat of the accused would have been following the victim's boat, and there would not have been a collision in the manner which led to the death of the victim. The one who is deliberate takes complete precaution when committing a crime and the collision would not take place in this surprising manner or speed. The report of the criminal laboratory stated that the boat of the defendant flew in the air during the collision at an angle of 45 degrees. This confirms the attempt of the defendant to avoid the incident in all ways which negates intent by the defendant while committing the crime. Therefore, the decision of the public prosecution is right in charging the defendant of manslaughter. Not treating the injured does not constitute a proof of deliberation, and the defendant said that it had been because he was attempted to treated the people injured with him, and that a man in such circumstances feels frightened, and this is shown by the attempt of the defendant to escape from the country after the incident. These two matters, not treating the victim and attempting to escape from the country, are not considered a proof of murder. The intent to murder is something that the perpetrator keeps to himself. The crime of murder requires a special intention to kill the victim. Nobody knows this intention except Allah, unless the tool used in the incident proves it, or unless it is proved by the circumstances of the incident and by the way in which it took place. This crime is a normal collision accident which happened due to the fault of the defendant who did not intend to kill the victim, for the reasons that the court has mentioned. The incident took place by mistake. Therefore the defendant will be punished for the crimes of manslaughter, causing injury and not treating the victims by imprisonment for one year, and be impelled to pay to the victim's heirs the blood money of 150.000 dirham and to hand this sum to the heirs in the court. The heirs will maintain the right to seek the value of damages that occurred to the property of the victim as a result of the incident, and the injured victim will maintain the right to seek compensation.
For these reasons the court passes the following sentences:

1.Convicting Eric Robert Bowra—Australian—Christian and 40 years old of the crime of manslaughter of Ibrahim Abdul Rahim Ahmed Al-Sheibani and of injuring the victim Khaled Ibrahim Abdul Rahim, and of not helping them. It punishes him for this by one year's imprisonment and by compelling him to pay to the heirs the legal blood money of 150.000 dirham, which has been received by the court and put in its safe in accordance with receipt no: 84574 and will be handed to the heirs according to normal procedure.

2.The rights of the injured Khaled Ibrahim Rahman Al-Sheibani and the rights of the heirs of the deceased Ibrahim Abdul Rahim Al-Sheibani to seek from the defendant civil compensation for injury and for the damage caused to the property of the victim are maintained.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on 10 November Senator Tambling asked me a question about sales tax on prefabricated homes. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has provided me with the following advice, based on advice he has received from the Commissioner of Taxation.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Taxation Office has advised a draft ruling in relation to the correct sales tax treatment of prefabricated homes. I emphasise that the ruling is only a draft one. The motivation for issuing the ruling is the inconsistency in the way in which businesses that manufacture prefabricated buildings deal with sales tax.

Some businesses pay sales tax on the taxable component of their prefabricated product and get their input sales tax free. Other businesses pay sales tax on their inputs and are not required to pay tax on their outputs. Different rates of sales tax are payable depending on the approach adopted.

The ATO has reviewed the industry with a view to ensuring consistency of treatment. As a result, it has issued a draft ruling. The ATO's view is that the law requires sales tax to be payable on the prefabricated buildings unless the manufacturer qualifies for the small business exemption. As is usual with draft rulings, the ATO is consulting with the relevant industry bodies.

The most recent consultations were on Friday, 11 November of last week, when, as I understand it, the ATO agreed to give the Housing Industry Association time to make a further submission on this ruling. The government is naturally interested in the outcome of the ATO's deliberations and will be kept informed by the Commissioner of Taxation.
There was an article in the Australian newspaper about this matter today. In the concluding lines of the article the following was said:

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, Senator Cook had been given a briefing at the beginning of last week.
This referred to my reply to Senator Tambling that I had no briefing before me.

PARA.TAB: I can say now that the journalist who wrote that comment did not contact my office, although he did say to one of my staff that he was going to pan me in a column. What he has said is not true at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to clarify information that I provided in this chamber on 11 October 1994 in response to a question from Senator Short. In my answer to that question I said that the December 1993 appointment of Mr Garth Head to the IRT had been announced at the time. I did so on the understanding that all such appointments of the executive council are routinely gazetted and therefore publicly announced. I have now been advised that this was not the case, although I note that Mr Head's appointment was advised in the IRT newsletter of 15 January 1994. I regret the error.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that, since its formation in 1989, appointments to the IRT have not, as a matter of course, been the subject of public announcement by press release—for example, the appointment of Mr Richard Phillips to the position of senior member in Sydney in October 1993. I have now instructed my department to ensure that all such appointments are henceforth gazetted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Senator Spindler asked me a question yesterday relating to coupe 50501. I have some further information on that matter provided by the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall).

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler's question related to whether this coupe had been increased from 27 hectares to 40 hectares. The answer, according to the advice I have received from the minister, is no. The area of compartment 50501 in the Hensleigh Creek area has always been 30 hectares. Nine hectares were logged in 1992-93. Last December approval was given for a further 14 hectares to be logged. In 1994-95 the remaining area is not to be logged.

The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has written to the Minister for Resources seeking advice and options for protecting Hensleigh Creek. The Minister for Resources has yet to receive formal advice from the minister for the environment on areas likely to have high conservation value. Until this occurs it is premature to say what action will be taken. However, honourable senators can be assured that Mr Beddall will consider all the relevant information in assessing export licence applications and will give careful consideration to advice provided to him by the minister for the environment and agencies within his portfolio.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 October 1994, Senator Coulter asked me a supplementary question on blood imports. I now have an answer that I will be seeking to incorporate in Hansard. Before I do so, I would also like to pass on my sympathy to Senator Coulter in his illness. I hope that he soon recovers. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Up until 1992 the Health Department advised AQIS approximately 100 times per month on controls to be applied to imported biological materials posing a possible human health concern. Only a small proportion of these applications were for human blood and blood derivatives, with the majority of these being for diagnostic use only. On average, less than one application per month was for human blood and blood derivatives to be imported for manufacturing purposes.

While copies of all advice to AQIS have been retained by the Health Department it would take a considerable amount of time to locate those few pertaining to human blood and blood derivatives imported for manufacturing purposes. However, these imports were subject only to standard conditions that would assist in safeguarding the health of the persons handling the materials.
These conditions required that the imported biological materials either:
be declared free from human pathogens, OR
be labelled with wording to the effect "This sample has not been screened for the presence of human pathogens. Appropriate biohazard precautions should be taken".

TALK.START.PARA: —Under procedural order No. 16, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs for an explanation as to when I might get an answer to question No. 1760, which I lodged on 11 October 1994, more than 30 days ago.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to give a formal answer to Senator Panizza now. I did indicate to Senator Panizza informally that the answer is being made available to the Table Office and, I think, will be available for him to peruse this afternoon. I am happy to respond, if he feels it appropriate, by reading the answer into Hansard. I am happy to table it or do whatever the Senate would wish. I can assure you, Mr Deputy President, that the answer is here in front of me. I am happy to table it—
—Incorporate it.
—I am happy to incorporate it. I seek leave to have this answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 12 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a report by Professors MacLennan and Smith and the announcement by the Minister that Australian Vietnam veterans will now be able to claim compensation for the effects of exposure to herbicides:
(1) On what date or dates were Professors MacLennan and Smith each commissioned to report on this matter.
(2) Exactly what were they asked to report on.
(3) What was the cost of this work.
(4) Will the Minister table a copy of the MacLennan/Smith report: if so, when.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Independent Expert Committee, consisting of Professor Robert MacLennan and Professor Peter Smith was commissioned by the Repatriation Commission on 29 September 1993.

(2) The Committee was asked to examine the United States National Academy of Sciences' report entitled Vietnam veterans: Health Effects of Herbicides Used in Vietnam within the following Terms of Reference:
Examine the Report of the National Academy of Sciences and comment on the scientific merit of the report;

Comment on the applicability of the findings of the Report to Australian servicemen and women, and in particular, the diseases listed as `limited/suggestive' of an association, and if needed, assist in the preparation of Statements of Principles that address these diseases;
Comment on the relevance of the Recommendations of the Report to Australian veterans.
(3) The total cost of the work undertaken by the Committee was $9,963.05.
(4) The copy will not be tabled but a copy has been provided to Senator Panizza under separate cover.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Short this day, relating to interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook's answer to me today, at least in part—I am not too sure whether it was deliberate or whether it was based just on his basic ignorance of the true facts—was wrong and, therefore, misleading to the Senate. He claimed that New Zealand interest rates are higher than interest rates in Australia. We were talking in the context of bond rates and long-term interest rates. Let me put it on the record that, according to the latest official statistics, Senator Cook is wrong.

PARA.TAB: The long-term interest rate in New Zealand in August was 8.35 per cent. In Australia it was 9.35 per cent and, indeed, between August and September the Australian rate went up a full percentage point to 10.35 per cent. I hope that Senator Cook will acknowledge that.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is right about the cash rates.
—We were talking about the basic underlying interest rates.
—The 90-day rate is nine per cent in Australia and 7.06 per cent in New Zealand.

—Senator Michael Baume has corrected the further ignorance that is shown by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The ignorance of Senator Gareth Evans does not surprise me because those opposite all get it wrong. My comments are directed particularly to Senator Cook, but Senator Evans, in his attempt to answer a question of Senator Hill's today, also made some fundamental errors and failed abysmally.

PARA.TAB: Let me get a couple of things on the record about interest rates which were not covered in Senator Cook's answer to my question and which should have been, if he were serious about attempting to answer the question. The fact is that interest rates in Australia are rising and that interest rates in Australia will rise further. The basic reason for both of those two irrefutable facts is that they are due overwhelmingly to the failure of the government's economic policies and, in particular, to its incredible laxity when it comes to budgetary or fiscal policy.

In regard to long-term bond rates in Australia today, which are a fundamental determiner of many other rates and help determine the rate structure in Australia, 10-year bonds are at 10.6 per cent in nominal terms and, in real terms, of the order of 7 1/2 per cent to eight per cent. At that real figure, they are the highest real interest rates that we have had in Australia for more than 30 years.

That 10-year bond rate has increased by 65 per cent this year alone. That is a rate of increase that is more than twice the rate in the United States, and it shows no signs of abating. The OECD, the industrialised world's economic think-tank, predicts that next year rates in Australia will be the highest of any industrialised country in the world.

This government tries to talk about making Australia internationally competitive and getting on with the game. All it is doing, through its policy failure, is to make it increasingly difficult for Australian businesses to do business and for Australian households to maintain a standard of living that ought to be theirs of right in a country such as ours.

If the government is so complacent about these facts, I commend to it the article in today's Australian Financial Review by its former Finance Minister, Peter Walsh, who points out that the current account deficit is blowing out in Australia; that the government's budget projections are slipping month by month; that interest rates are the highest for years; and that many of the other fundamental economic factors underlying the economy are going from bad to worse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook set out to mislead this Senate, and he behaved disgracefully. He found one interest rate, among all the range of interest rates, that was 0.4 of one per cent lower in Australia than it is in New Zealand. Every other interest rate indicator of any substance shows New Zealand interest rates massively below Australian interest rates.

PARA.TAB: What an incredible thing for a minister of the Crown to set out to mislead the parliament like this, using the most selective quotation, particularly when all the trends are going massively against Australia, while in New Zealand, of course, the situation, despite a remarkable growth rate double Australia's, shows nothing like the sorts of problems that this government has visited upon Australia.

Let us get the facts so that Senator Evans will be at last informed, because he, being the representative of the government in the Senate, is probably the most incompetent Leader of the Government we have ever had in this place in terms of understanding what is going on in the economy. Let us look at the facts of the call money market. There is no doubt that that is the only market that Senator Cook referred to. That in Australia was 5.5 per cent overnight, when New Zealand was 5.9 per cent.

Let us look at the 90-day bill market—7.06 per cent in New Zealand and nine per cent in Australia; the five-year bond market—8.35 per cent in New Zealand and 10.35 per cent in Australia; and the first mortgage housing rate—8.8 per cent in New Zealand and 9.5 per cent in Australia. Here we have a farrago of nonsense being presented by Senator Cook.

It is almost as bad as the nonsense we got from Senator Evans himself when he said that there were no fundamentals to justify rising interest rates in Australia. I do not know which fundamentals Senator Evans had in mind, but there is one that strikes me—and he seems to be talking through it. The fact is very simple indeed.

The greatest fundamental in terms of why Australian interest rates are going up is the balance of payments. Can I let him into a secret, because he obviously does not know it: the September quarter current account deficit of Australia is the worst ever in our history. It is $7 billion. I do not know whether that has ever entered his consciousness, but it means that in Australian interest rates there is built in a premium for the risk involved of foreigners, in particular, buying Australian dollars. That is dramatised in all the recognised expert opinions on what is happening in Australia.
