The fundamental fact is that the markets are concerned about the future of the Australian dollar and how it will need interest rate protection to keep people, foreigners in particular, being prepared to hold Australian dollars. Why are we worried about foreigners holding Australian dollars? It is because we have this massive, record, continual collapse in Australia's current account which this government is quite prepared to live with.

Australians, I fear, do not recognise what the consequences are every time there is one of these massive balance of payments deficits. It hits their interest rates; it hits the mortgage rates that are so much higher in Australia than in New Zealand. It hits the mortgage rates of ordinary Australians who now are going to the industrial tribunals seeking huge increases in their wages. This is inflationary and, therefore, Australia is being priced out of more markets. As a consequence of this government's incompetent fiscal policy, interest rates have to rise.

Of course, former Senator Walsh knows all about this and he explained to economic oafs like Senator Evans exactly what the facts are. It is a pity that Senator Evans did not listen to Senator Walsh when he had the opportunity to do so in the cabinet because if he had, at least he may have become economically literate instead of trying to pretend, along with his colleague Senator Cook, that the government knows what it is doing. The consequences of its actions are disastrous for Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I am an economic oaf, I am in pretty good company because the briefs that I have on this matter reflect the considered opinion of Treasury—they are a pretty sophisticated bunch of economists over there—and, of course, reflect the government's total economic strategy, which is the product of many minds other than my own. Long-term bond yields, as even Senator Baume ought to be prepared to frankly acknowledge, are determined by the market, not the government. They are affected by a range of international factors which are quite outside the control of this or any other government in this country.
—The balance of payments. Didn't you listen?

—I will come to that in a moment. Australian long-term bond yields reflect the market's judgment about a whole series of factors, including likely future real interest rates and inflationary expectations that are built into those; past inflation performance; and developments in other bond markets such as the United States. Some of the recent rise in Australian yields seems certainly to have reflected the recent weakening in the US bond market in that respect.
—And the balance of payments. You haven't admitted that yet.

—The balance of payments comes into the equation in terms of people's perspectives. But in doing that, it ought to be appreciated that, while the current account situation is certainly not as comfortable as we would like it to be, our debt service ratio, which measures the capacity to handle the current account deficit in terms of the quantum or the proportion of exports, is in very good shape indeed. Part of that is contingent on exchange rate movements, so it jumps around a bit but it is running at the moment at around 11 or 12 per cent. That puts us in very good company internationally compared with other countries which have balance of payments difficulties.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, our overall public debt relative to GDP is very low by international standards and that ought to be properly reflected and acknowledged as well. If we are going to have a genuinely sustained low inflationary environment of a kind which the international money markets ought to be prepared to concede, as they are not at the moment, obviously we have to adjust both our fiscal and monetary policy in a way as to ensure that.

The decisions that we have taken both in relation to fiscal consolidation and in relation to those interest rates that are within our capacity to control, namely the short-term cash rates and those rates that are contingent upon them, have demonstrated that the government is prepared to take the hard decisions to ensure this outcome. There is absolutely no reason for our credibility to be questioned or threatened in this respect.

On the interest rate side, the monetary authorities have already reacted decisively and pre-emptively to ensure that low inflation is maintained. That has been widely acknowledged by commentators in the marketplace domestically as an appropriate course to take.

So far as fiscal tightening is concerned, it is the case that the 1994-95 budget estimates are that the deficit is expected to be under one per cent of GDP by 1996-97 and approaching balance in 1997-98. That fiscal target and our capacity to achieve it compare very favourably indeed with those of the G7 countries, which have announced targets, and indeed compare favourably right now with their performance.

I said in response to Senator McMullan's interjection that our budget deficit position is really very good by international standards. Compare the figures at the moment: our 1993 figures reflecting the 1992-93 outcomes indicate 3.6 per cent for us. Compare that with the United States, 3.6 per cent; France, 4.5 per cent; Italy, 9.7 per cent; UK, 7.8 per cent; Canada, six per cent; with only Germany, at 2.2 per cent, being underneath us.

In terms of the target deficits that we are chasing, Australia's one per cent in 1996-97 compares very favourably with the three per cent that Canada expects and hopes to achieve, the 5.8 per cent that Italy is targeting, the 2.5 per cent in 1997 that France is targeting, the 1.3 per cent in 1997 that Germany is targeting and the 2.3 per cent that the United States is targeting for fiscal year 1997-98. Only the UK, which is chasing zero per cent in 2000—three years after that—has a target less than ours. We hope, of course, to achieve that zero per cent, that balance, a year or two earlier than that.

So in terms of comparative performance right now in budget deficit terms we are, exactly as I said in question time, looking very good by comparison with the rest of the world, including the trading countries with whom we normally compare ourselves. That is the environment. The economic fundamentals are there.

So far as the assault on Senator Cook's integrity is concerned, might I draw Senator Michael Baume's attention to the most up-to-date data I have in front of me at the moment, from the back page of the Far East Economic Review from 17 November, which compares interest rates around the region. In both Australia and New Zealand the prime lending rate—I say to Senator Baume that that is pretty significant for business decision making—is 9.5 per cent. If we look at the interbank rates, we see that one month, three months and six months out we will be a damn sight better than New Zealand for each of those three periods. That is the reality of the matter. There are some other figures—

TALK.START.PARA: —He was overwhelmingly wrong and you are defending him.

—No; I have here some other notes, which I cannot decipher. But in terms of the prime lending rate, which does matter to business, the figures are identical and a damn sight better looking out to the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some figures here on the prime rates. They show that Australia's prime rate is 10.5 per cent, which, I have to say—
—Quote the source.

—These figures are in the Economist. On that basis, we would have to say that Senator Cook was not only wrong—he was comprehensively wrong. I think two fundamental statements were made today in question time, and I think they are worth re-recording. They are: why are Australia's long-term real interest rates, as measured by 10-year bond rates, now at their highest for over 30 years, and why has the OECD recently predicted that Australia will have the highest long-term interest rates of any of its members in 1995?

PARA.TAB: It is all very well for Senator Gareth Evans to come into this chamber and make certain claims about what he thinks his government is doing, but the bottom line, as measured by real interest rates, is that we are amongst the worst performers in the world. And it is interest rates that have a major effect on living standards, particularly in relation to young home owners, a major effect on employment and a major effect on investment.

Senator McKiernan is in the chamber, and he will no doubt have read this morning the comments made by his former colleague Senator Walsh, a former Finance Minister in this government. He gave a totally different picture from the one that Senator Evans tried to paint for us. The former Senator Walsh—as I said, a former ALP Finance Minister—in the article headed `Banana road to republic', pointed out that the current account deficit is blowing out, probably to five per cent of GDP or more. Perhaps this is one of the major reasons why interest rates in this country are so high.

Senator Evans conceded that the balance of payments had some effect. Perhaps that is one of the reasons why the real level of interest rates in this country happens to be so high. I again turn to the Economist. I think Senator Evans's staff would be better advised to give him the Economist because it would help him to get his figures right on certain key points. In regard to the balance of payments, the Economist has a table which compares Australia's balance of payments performance with 12 to 15 other industrialised economies. The figures in the Economist show that Australia's balance of payments performance is not only currently the worst amongst OECD countries but is also predicted to get worse.

Senator Evans came into this chamber and said that we had a wonderful conjunction of economic figures. We have the highest real interest rates for 30 years, the highest real interest rates in the OECD area, and the worst balance of payments figures in the OECD area. I put it to Senator Evans, as Senator Walsh undoubtedly pointed out to Senator Evans in his article this morning, that there are some major fundamentals in this country which are going sour. Senator Evans mentioned the budget. These are Senator Walsh's views compared with Senator Evans's:

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget—which according to One Nation's slack fiscal objectives was supposed to be in surplus next year—
Does Senator Evans remember that? He came in here and told us it would be in surplus next year.
is now projected to be still in deficit 1 per cent of GDP the year after next.
He goes on to say:
That permissive target recedes every time (about every second month recently) the structural Budget deficit gets blown out by a "statement" on something or another.

I put it to Senator Evans that there are serious problems in the economy. It ill-behoves Senator Evans and Senator Cook—who I concede is the junior minister, but who undoubtedly takes his lead from Senator Evans—to come in here and pretend that everything in the economy is lovely, but find it absolutely impossible to explain why interest rates in Australia are at record levels. I suggest that Senator Evans should go back to his office and get a decent briefing for a change.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Tierney this day, relating to the effects of drought on the rural sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I deal with this, I would like to express some sadness at the fact that this afternoon ministers, one after the other, have given a whole series of misleading answers. Members of the public who are listening would have the wool pulled totally over their eyes. As a trained economist, I was appalled by the answer given by Senator Gareth Evans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there such a thing as a trained economist?

—Yes, the minister would not know about that. I was also appalled by the answer then given by the Senator Cook, who outlined a load of absolute economic nonsense in question time when it is broadcast on television and radio. No wonder the standing of politicians is so low when senior members of the government tell blatant lies, or `Richos' as we now call them.

PARA.TAB: The worst answer this afternoon came from Senator Collins. The lies that he told are outlined in the Hansard record. He said that I had suddenly discovered an interest in the drought. The Hansard record for the last 55 days reveals that I mentioned the word `drought' in this chamber on 78 occasions in a series of notices of motions, speeches and taking note of answers. It is outrageous for this minister to come into this place and make such an accusation. Is it not smart of him? We are no longer in question time and the audience has basically gone, but he has made this lying point, and it is on the Hansard record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tierney, I am sure there is a more delicate way of expressing your disbelief. `Lying' is not a word I accept.

—He was telling `Richos' again. I just want to set the Hansard record straight. Not only have I spoken about this matter in the chamber but I have also constantly visited drought affected areas. I was with Senator Sandy Macdonald up on a stump 20 kilometres north of Kyogle with 50 farmers a few weeks ago. Next week, I will return with Senator Troeth and Mrs Judy Moylan, one of the shadow ministers, to places that Senator Collins would not even know existed, such as Old Bonalbo, Coraki and Tyalgum. They are out the back of the northern part of New South Wales, which has suffered from the devastating effects of this drought and the lack of proper government response and policy.

PARA.TAB: The whole point of my question this afternoon was to draw the minister out on the issue of what he is doing to protect farms and the business units in rural Australia. I was not asking the minister a question about social welfare matters, even though the government has introduced such measures. These measures are totally inadequate because they apply only to areas of extreme drought and only four per cent of farmers are getting any relief.

In northern New South Wales the Labor member for Page, Mr Harry Woods, was asked about what should happen. He replied, `Well, they can always get money from the Farmhand appeal.' That is an outrageous statement on public policy. The Farmhand money is welcome and has done quite a lot of good, but it is money raised from the public to help people in desperate situations on farms because this government has not come up with an appropriate policy response.

I would like to contrast what this federal Labor government has not done with what has been done by the Fahey government in New South Wales. Even though the New South Wales government has greater restrictions than the federal government, it brought in measures amounting to $22 million in August and $60 million more recently. The New South Wales government has given local government relief, matched rural adjustment scheme money, provided relief on electricity accounts, provided funding for humane treatment of stock, provided for plant seeding projects, fodder and water trains, and the carriage of charitable goods, and has allowed grazing on crown land.

Where is the federal government response to such excellent measures in New South Wales? The federal government has put out a minor amount of money for social welfare, but in terms of protecting rural Australia's business and farm units so that we have something left to build on after this drought, this government has done nothing and it deserves the condemnation of this parliament and the people of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Mifepristone
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned showeth:

(1) That the trials of the abortifacient drug Mifepristone (RU486) are against the public interest in that they use women as guinea pigs for trials of a drug which causes death to the unborn future citizens and adds undue risk to the health of women.
(2) That when RU486 is used with a prostaglandin it exposes women to a disproportionate risk of pain, bleeding and more serious complications.
(3) That when RU486 is used as a `morning after pill' its effect is abortifacient in that it stops implantation of a human embryo, a future citizen, in the womb.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will legislate to ban the importation and use of RU486 in Australia.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Tierney (from 315 citizens) and Senator West (from 162 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Chemical Registration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to introduce legislation that will require the National Registration Authority to provide all available information on registered chemicals.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Provisional Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
This petition of the undersigned signed shows that:

(a)provisional tax bills for small businesses are too high because the 8 percent `uplift factor' or inflation factor is set too high by the Federal Government, and that this adversely affects cashflows and job creating capacity, and
(b)they are disappointed that although the Liberal/National Coalition have been critical of the level of the `uplift factor' they may not support moves to lower it.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:
*Amend the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill No. 3 1994 to reduce the uplift factor to 5 percent as moved by the Australian Democrats.

PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes attempts by the government to raise the pension age for women from 60 to 65 years.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate oppose this proposed change.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training Reference Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matters be referred to the Employment, Education and Training References Committee for inquiry and report on or before 29 June 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: The past, present and likely future trends in long-term unemployment and the patterns of work and unemployment among older workers, particularly those who have been made redundant or who have taken early retirement. In its inquiry, the committe will:

PARA.TAB: (a)examine the research on the causes of long-term unemployment, assess the extent to which the causal factors are likely to persist, and examine the risks of exploitation to which this group are exposed;

(b)evaluate the established programs and current opportunities which enable the long-term unemployed to return to the work force, either as employees or as self-employed, and identify any legislative or other regulatory mechanisms which might constrain those opportunities; and
(c)identify, describe and evaluate alternative, innovative strategies being implemented in Australia and elsewhere to:

TAB.TAB: (i)re-engage the long-term unemployed, and
(ii)achieve generally higher levels of work force participation,

PARA.TAB: these could include efforts to re-organise and re-distribute work and new forms of work organisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that 15 sitting days after today I shall move that the following delegated legislation be disallowed:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Exemption No BKFO/59/94, made under Civil Aviation Regulation 207
2.Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1994 No 325, made under the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984
3.Citizen Band Radio Stations Licence, made under s.132(1) of the Radiocommunications Act 1992
4.Handphone Stations (27 MHz) Class Licence, made under s.132(1) of the Radiocommunications Act 1992
5.Instrument No 45 of 1994, made under s.196B(3) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986
6.Suspension of a Regional Councillor from Office No 1 of 1994, made under s.122A of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989
I seek leave to make a short statement about the committee's concerns with this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee's concerns with these instruments include a discretion with no indication whether subject to review, possible invalidity, prejudicial retrospectivity and possible breaches of personal rights. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the matters raised by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Exemption No BKFO/59/94 made under Regulation 207 of the Civil Aviation Act 1994
The instrument exempts Impulse Airlines Pty Limited from the provisions of Civil Aviation Order 20.11, subsection 9, in relation to the use of emergency lighting, subject to specified conditions.

The rule-maker stated in the body of the instrument that it was being made by a delegate of the Civil Aviation Authority. The rule-maker signed the instrument, however, for and on behalf of the Civil Aviation Authority. These designations do not appear to be consistent. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on who was the rule-maker in this case and whether the inconsistency has any implications for validity.

Also, the instrument does not indicate the day on which it was made, although the instrument is expressed to be effective from 8 September 1994. If, however, the instrument was made and was effective on that date, then unless it was also gazetted on that date it appears to be void under s.48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. As well, the intention of the instrument, which is reflected in the explanatory statement, is that Impulse Airlines may act contrary to a specified Civil Aviation Order. Regulation 207, however, under which the instrument was made, does not appear to provide a power to exempt anyone from the Civil Aviation Orders or permit anyone to operate contrary to the Orders. The Committee has asked the Minister for advice on these matters.
Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1994 No 325
These Regulations increase the amount of professional indemnity insurance cover.

New r.2B(3)(a) confers a discretion on the Commissioner which may have important implications for the operation of a business. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice as to whether there are any criteria in the Regulations for the exercise of the discretion, whether its exercise is subject to AAT review and, if not, for assurance that this is within the relevant guidelines of the Administrative Review Council and the Attorney-General's Department.
Citizen Band Radio Stations Licence, made under s.132(1) of the Radiocommunications Act 1992
Handphone Stations (27 Mhz) Class Licence, made under s.132(1) of the Radiocommunications Act 1992
These Instruments provide for conditions under which the holders of a citizen band radio licence and a 27 Mhz handphone licence respectively, must operate.

Clause 8 of the former instrument and clause 7 of the latter provide for circumstances in which directions may be given relating to the operation of a station and set out the persons who may give such directions. The circumstances are where there might be interference to radiocommunications which may endanger an aircraft or emergencies relating to the environment, risk of death or injury to persons or substantial damage to property. The persons who may give directions are police, Defence Force officers, officers of the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre and certain prescribed officers.

These provisions appear appropriate and reasonable, but the Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice as to which provisions of the parent Act authorise the conferral of these powers to give directions.
Instrument No 45 of 1994, made under s.196B(3) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986
This Instrument makes an amendment relating to gastro-oesophageal reflux disease.

The Instrument amends retrospectively an earlier Instrument by removing the phrase "of the pancreas", which the Explanatory Notes advise was a typographical error. While this may be the case, the Committee has written to the Minister seeking assurance that deleting the phrase could not disadvantage someone retrospectively who was relying on the original Instrument which contained the phrase.
Suspension of a Regional Councillor from Office No 1 of 1994, made under s.122A of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989
This Instrument suspends a named officer from the exercise of office. Such instruments are subject to parliamentary scrutiny.

The Committee is concerned about possible breaches of personal rights resulting from the exercise of this power of suspension. The instrument may not have been made in accordance with the enabling legislation.
The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on the matter.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Finance and Public Administration References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Finance and Public Administration References Committee for inquiry and report:

SPEECH.PARA: Service delivery by the Australian Public Service, with particular reference to:

PARA.TAB: (a)the impact of public service reforms on the structure and standards of service delivery;
(b)the quality of, and accountability for, Commonwealth Government programs delivered by state, local government and non-government agencies;
(c)the effectiveness of the measures taken to improve service quality and the methods by which effectiveness is assessed;
(d)the response to feedback provided by recipients of services; and
(e)options for further improving the quality of service delivery.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Joint Standing Committee on Migration be authorised to hold a public hearing during the sitting of the Senate on 16 November 1994 from 4 p.m. until the adjournment of the Senate, for the purpose of taking evidence for the committee's inquiry into the Immigration Review Tribunal appointment process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)condemns:

TAB.TAB: (i)the United States (US) for acting in contradiction to the United Nations (UN) embargo against arms sales to any party in Bosnia, and
(ii)as a sign of contempt of its allies, actions of the US in its unilateral lifting of a UN arms embargo without negotiation;

PARA.TAB: (b)expresses in the strongest possible terms that this partisan approach is likely to increase the number of people, including non-combatants, who will be killed or injured;
(c)requests that the US honours its commitments to peace and to the UN in a consistent way; and
(d)expresses its regret that the US Government appears to believe it can push for UN actions supporting its agenda when it suits, and ignore UN decisions when convenient.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the callous comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who, in the week beginning 6 November 1994, ruled out any further assistance to farmers to feed starving stock claiming, inaccurately, that the Government had got the right mix of assistance in place,
(ii)that farmer organisations now estimate that up to 70 per cent of breeding stock could be lost if the drought continues,

(iii)that there is no evidence to suggest the drought is about to break and therefore the current crisis is now closer to a national catastrophe, with the lack of feed, water and money affecting increasing numbers of rural communities, and

(iv)that the fallout from this tragedy will be a massive shift in the structure, ownership and financial soundness of the entire rural sector, a sector which will take years to readjust to pre-drought levels of production and profitability; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Government to acknowledge that the drought has expanded beyond all its best estimates and predictions and accept that the current strategies are inappropriate and inadequate and that they must be strengthened.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)notes, with deep concern, the events which took place at Oyster Point on the Hinchinbrook Channel on 14 November 1994 when people protesting the resort development by Mr Keith Williams were forcibly removed from the site;
(b)condemns the Queensland Government for rushing the gazettal of the public land, which took 24 hours instead of the normal 21 days;

(c)regrets the total inaction of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) in failing to use his powers to protect the world heritage area of Hinchinbrook Channel from the inevitable damage it will suffer by the resort development; and
(d)calls on the Federal Government to immediately exercise its powers to stop the development in order to protect the area and the endangered species that inhabit it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes the formation of a Hunter Regional Development Organisation (HURDO) which has been established to attract federal regional development funds;
(b)condemns the Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government for creating an umbrella body that is unrepresentative in its make up and stacked with Labor politicians;

(c)reminds the ALP Government that the Kelty Taskforce report recommended that regional organisations should not be subject to political party pressure, but notes that HURDO has three sitting ALP members with no other party political members represented;

(d)condemns the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Mr Howe) for failing to appoint to the HURDO women, aborigines, environmentalists or indeed representatives of the large pool of unemployed people in the Hunter region created by the ALP Government's economic policies;

(e)calls on the ALP Government to stop falsely raising the expectations of regions like the Hunter with misleading promises of an Australia-wide $150 million plan for regional development, when it is clear that the Hunter region will only receive a fraction of this promised funding for the development of its regional development organisation secretariat and infrastructure;

(f)condemns the ALP Government for not communicating to regions the fine print of its offer which sees the $150 million to be spent over 4 years and to be shared across 66 regions, with the capital cities able to access the money in competition with regional Australia; and

(g)asks the ALP Government to explain how it can run an effective regional development policy for all Australia when it will spend only a paltry $10 million in 1994 in infrastructure capital works across the country under this policy, with the Hunter region receiving virtually nothing for infrastructure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the claims by Mr Keating, when Treasurer in the late 1980s, as referred to by Ms Laura Tingle in the Australian of 14 November 1994, that only the Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government could deliver the budgetary and structural changes required to make the economy internationally competitive without dragging the nation into a recession,

(ii)that not only did Australia subsequently have its worst post-war recession, but the structural changes have done nothing to correct the basic problem of a disastrous balance of payments deficit, with the latest September 1994 quarterly current account deficit of $7 billion being the worst quarterly deficit ever recorded, and
(iii)that despite having undertaken not to drag Australia into a recession, Mr Keating then dragged Australia into the recession he said we had to have; and

PARA.TAB: (b)expresses its concern that Mr Keating appears to be using the same approach to the truth as his former factional and ministerial colleague, former Senator Richardson.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Finance and Public Administration References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Finance and Public Administration References Committee for inquiry and report:

SPEECH.PARA: The management of real property within the Australian Public Service, with particular reference to:

PARA.TAB: (a)the process undertaken, including the criteria used by Commonwealth Government departments and agencies, in deciding to lease, purchase or build commercial accommodation;
(b)the extent of, and rationale for, Commonwealth participation in the ongoing management of commercial property; and
(c)the extent to which overall efficiency in the use of office accommodation and other commercial properties by the Commonwealth is achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)deplores the actions of the Indonesian military in Dili in its response to the rally to mark the anniversary of the Dili massacre;
(b)notes that the use of tear gas to disperse the mourners indicates a continuation of Indonesian suppression of peaceful public gatherings in East Timor; and
(c)calls on the Australian Government:

TAB.TAB: (i)to withdraw from all defence co-operation arrangements with Indonesia,
(ii)to end all military training of members of the Indonesian armed forces in Australia or by Australian personnel, and
(iii)to join the United States Government in banning arms sales to Indonesia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) released official figures in June 1994 that show a breakdown of the effects of unemployment on Australian families;
(b)condemns:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government for pursuing policies that the ABS figures reveal are having a shocking impact on Australian families, with one in ten traditional families having both parents out of work, and
(ii)the ALP Government's policy settings that have produced official figures to show that, of this nation's 4.7 million families, 1.1 million of those families have no breadwinner;

PARA.TAB: (c)records disgust at the information in the ABS figures which highlights the fact that 19 per cent or over 700 000 young Australians under 15 years of age live in a family situation where no one has a job of any kind;

(d)calls on the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the ALP Government to come clean and admit the accuracy of these devastating figures and desist from saying the official ABS statistics outlining the impact of unemployment on families are `misleading data'; and
(e)demands that these frightening figures be addressed immediately with effective public labour market policies that will assist the plight of Australian families.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes the protest by supporters of East Timorese independence at the offices of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Darwin;
(b)congratulates the protesters for keeping this issue before the Australian public; and
(c)notes the demands of the protesters, namely, that the Australian Government:

TAB.TAB: (i)withdraw Australia's de jure recognition of the Indonesian takeover of East Timor in 1975,
(ii)withdraw from the East Timor Gap Treaty until the World Court is able to rule on the treaty's legality,

(iii)hold a royal commission within Australia into the role of Australian-elected representatives and public institutions into the invasion of East Timor, its subsequent cover-up and Australia's ongoing diplomatic support for Indonesia's occupation,
(iv)bring genuine diplomatic and economic pressure to bear on Indonesia to find a fair resolution to the problem, and
(v)remove Senator Gareth Evans from his position as Minister for Foreign Affairs as he has shown himself unable or unwilling to acknowledge the true extent of the problem in East Timor.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Finance and Public Administration References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: the current account deficit is blowing out—probably to 5 per cent of GDP or more;
the Budget, which according to One Nation's slack fiscal objectives was supposed to be in surplus next year—is now projected to be still in deficit by 1 per cent of GDP the year after next;
that permissible target recedes every time (about every second month recently) the structural Budget deficit gets blown out by a `statement' on something of other;
largely because of slack fiscal policy, interest rates have been rising. The 10-year bond rate is higher in real terms than it was in 1989-90;
the consequential increase in the $A value will put additional pressure on the current account; and

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) claimed in response to a question without notice from Senator Short on 15 November 1994 that New Zealand interest rates are higher than Australian interest rates,

(ii)the publication of comparable long-term interest rates issued on 14 November 1994 by the Parliamentary Library reveals that the New Zealand market rate of 8.35 per cent on Government bonds in August 1994 is 1 percentage point below the Australian rates for August 1994 and 2 percentage points below the September 1994 Australian rate,

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on Senator Cook to cease misleading the Senate in his futile attempt to defend his incompetent Government.
Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:

Motion (by Senator Reid)—as amended by leave—agreed to:

(b)acknowledges that Suu Kyi won a landslide victory as Leader of the National League for Democracy in 1990 despite her inability to campaign, and that she is the rightful leader of that nation;

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate a matter that has been brought to my attention regarding the Sizzler chain of restaurants. For the information of the Senate, the Sizzler chain has some 92 restaurant outlets in this country. It is relatively new upon the Australian scene, having been here for only the last couple of years, but it has experienced fantastic growth. It is a United States based concept and it has enjoyed many of the advantages of this country.

PARA.TAB: It has also been brought to my attention that the Sizzler chain, for the first time known in this particular industry, is importing United States beef. It is, indeed, importing into this country the largest single shipment known of United States beef. It does not show loyalty to its suppliers at all—that is, the Australian farming sector—so I think the Australian customers who have patronised this particular outlet should not show the same loyalty in return for this particular act.

I am informed by an article in the Weekly Times today that that beef shipment will be on the restaurant tables around Christmas and New Year. The Sizzler chain is intent on making the difficult situation of Australian farmers, namely, the drought, even more miserable just around Christmas time.

Australians would get amusement out of the fact that this particular chain of restaurants happens to use in its advertising campaigns that well-known Australian Kieren Perkins, the champion Australian swimmer and gold medallist in the Commonwealth Games and the Olympic Games. That is a laugh. That is misusing a good man, a well-known Australian, when all the time through the backdoor it is screwing Australian suppliers.

The reasons given by the spokesmen of Sizzler do not hold up. They are blaming the drought. Talk about walking out on stricken Australian farmers at a time of need! Sizzler has been far too quick to walk out on them. Australians have not walked out on them generally. Even this government at last has come to the aid of the farmers with a package. Australians have extended the hand of charity to the Australian farming sector and generally the nation has pulled together for the plight of the farmers.

While we cannot force Sizzler to use Australian beef, we would have expected a bit more generosity in this particular aspect because of the plight of the Australian farmers. Its excuses do not hold up. Price is not a factor; it has admitted that itself. One of Sizzler's purchasers, the Sydney based Beak and Johnston, said that price, supply and quality were not an issue. They are all matters—price, supply and quality—which Sizzler has agreed are not an issue.

The Cattle Council of Australia says that prices have fallen since last year and premium cattle in Australia still cost less than those in the US. In relation to supply, the proportion of the national kill which was female was rising and was particularly concerning for the production potential of Australia. In other words, Australian farmers are unloading their cattle onto the market, so the cattle yards are actually full at the moment. That may be a different story down the track.

I think that the Australian customers of Sizzler should blackball this particular chain of restaurants and certainly should be writing to the chain requesting an answer as to why it is not sticking by the Australian farmers if price, quality and supply are not legitimate reasons. It is going to make Christmas for the Australian farmers rather miserable. If this particular American beef is to land on the tables of Sizzler during Christmas and the New Year, then we should equally in return make Sizzler's Christmas sales miserable.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: The following documents were tabled:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Housing and Regional Development: Office Space

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, upon notice, on 7 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many square metres of office space are either leased, owned or occupied by the department and its agencies.
(2) What is the breakdown by State or Territory, and by department and agency, by State or Territory.
(3) How many department and agency employees occupy the office space.
(4) What is the breakdown, by State or Territory, and by department and agency, by State or Territory.

(5) Does the department lease or own any office space which is not currently occupied by staff; if so, please supply details of: (a) whether the office space is leased or owned; (b) whether it is leased/owned by the department or one of its agencies; (c) how many square metres are involved and the location of the office space (please specify whether details of these office space properties are included in the answers to any of the above questions).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are 9,777.29m(2) of office space either leased, owned or occupied by the Department. (Refer to table below for the National Capital Planning Authority).
(2) The breakdown by State and Territory for the Department is:

ANSWER.PARA: * Includes 1083.8m(2) leased on a temporary basis pending fitout of new accommodation.

PARA.TAB: (3) As at 30 June 1994 there were a total of 357 Department and agency employees occupying the office space (full time equivalents). However, because the Department is newly created, it is currently significantly below approved staffing levels. The Department will be looking to accommodate approximately 480 persons following its current recruitment drive.
(4) The breakdown by State and Territory, at 30 June 1994 was:

(5) The Department currently leases 425m(2) of office space at the Plaza Shopfront at 51 Allara Street, Canberra. This office space was transferred to the Department as part of the creation of the new portfolio; however, it is sub-let to the Department of Industry, Science and Technology and occupied by that Department's officers. The Department is also subleasing 58.94m(2) of previously unoccupied space to a private tenant in its Queensland Office.
The program of National Capital Planning is managed by the National Capital Planning Authority (NCPA) and receives its own appropriation of funds for Property Operating Expenses.
(1) The National Capital Planning Authority leases and occupies 1284m2 of office space.
(2) All of this space is located in the Australian Capital Territory.
(3) As at 30 June 1994, there were a total of 78 NCPA employees occupying this office space.
(4) All of these employees and contractors are located in the Australian Capital Territory.
(5) The NCPA does not lease or own any office space which is currently not occupied by staff.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a report on page 32 of the Aviation Week and Space Technology of 4 April 1994 that all three Defence Support Program (DSP) satellites observed the A1 Abbas Iraqi Scud attack which killed 28 United States (US) soldiers during Desert Storm but a full missile warning report was not forwarded from the DSP network because of a `worst-case combination of events':
(1) Is the Minister aware of this event.
(2) Can the Minister confirm reports that the United States Air Force (USAF) commander of Nurrungar, Colonel Hess, was court-marshalled for negligence earlier in 1994 in relation to these matters.

(3) Who, and what, was responsible for the mishaps in reading data from DSP Flights No. 12 and No. 15; (b) were the people responsible court-marshalled; (c) with what were they charged, and how were they punished; and (d) what were their names, ranks and nationalities.
(4) Were any Australian operators charged or court-marshalled as a result of the USAF report; if not, why not.
(5) Were any Australian personnel involved in operating equipment used to read data from DSP Flights No. 12 and No. 15.
(6) Do Australian personnel operate in the sensitive areas in which Nurrungar is involved, and please detail their roles.

(7) Does the Australian Government believe that Nurrungar's role contributed to the deaths of the 28 US soldiers, and is the Government therefore ready to pay compensation to the families of the deceased; if not, why not.
(8) Does the Australian Government have a copy of the USAF report on Nurrungar's negligence and inefficiency; if so, can a copy be provided; if not, why not.
(9) Does the Government believe that Australian officials should be informed of such a report in light of the fact that Nurrungar is a joint facility.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1), (3) and (4) Yes. I am aware of the attack on the Dhahran barracks in which 28 US service personnel died and of the important role which Nurrungar played in monitoring Scud missile launches throughout the Gulf War, which I outlined to the Senate on 5 November 1991 (Senate Hansard page 2374). Beyond this, I have nothing to add on the Facility's operations, in keeping with the Government's longstanding policy of not commenting on our intelligence capabilities.

A US Army investigation of the incident concluded that the Scud missile attack succeeded because two Patriot missile batteries deployed to protect the Dhahran Air Base were unable to engage the Scud. The first was undergoing repairs to a radar receiver at the time, and was therefore out of action, while the other experienced an inexact computer calculation and was unable to detect the incoming missile. The US Army also concluded that, even if there had been earlier warning of the Scud attack, the resulting deaths would still have occurred as the soldiers would have followed their instructions to remain in the building or would have entered after the alert if they were outside.
As the actions of operators of the system supported by Nurrungar played no part in this unfortunate incident, no disciplinary action was ever contemplated against any Nurrungar personnel.
(2) There is no truth to these reports.

(5) & (6) I have nothing to add to Prime Minister Hawke's statement in the Parliament of 22 November 1988 in which he noted that `the integration of Australian personnel in both the operation and the management of the Joint Facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar is such that the Australian Government can be assured of having full knowledge of all aspects of the operations at the Facilities, and reinforces our confidence that our interests and sovereignty are respected at all times'.
(7) No. See answer to parts (1), (3) and (4) above.

(8) & (9) The USAF has advised that there is no such USAF report. I can say though that Australia does have access to the information which supports the conclusions reached in the answer to parts (1), (3) and (4).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 5 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that at the Roads and Traffic Authority/NRMA meeting on 11 May 1994 the bull bar industry was granted the opportunity to conduct independent tests and report back to the regulatory authorities.
(2) Is the Minister aware that the bull bar industry has also undertaken to produce a mandatory Australian standard to cover bull bar design and fitting.

(3) In light of the question without notice asked of the Minister on 29 June 1994 concerning the consequences of Australian Design Rule 69 on bull bar manufacture and the reply from the Minister for Transport of 29 July 1994, does this mean that the regulators have pre-empted the conclusions of the independent tests of the bull bar industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The Australian Design Rules (ADRs) are National Standards under the Federal Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989. A bull bar manufacturer needs to be able to demonstrate that the product does not affect compliance of the vehicle with the standards.

(2) No. At the Bullbar Workshop sponsored by the New South Wales Roads and Traffic Authority and the NRMA, mention was made of a voluntary Code of Practice by the bullbar industry covering bullbar design and fitment.

(3) No. Some vehicle manufacturers have already conducted crash tests which indicate that the fitment of a bullbar will affect the crash performance of the vehicle. One local manufacturer has developed a bullbar which has been integrally designed into the airbag safety system to ensure that compliance with ADR 69 is not affected. It is understood that another local manufacturer is developing a bullbar for its family sedan which is compatible with its airbag system. It was acknowledged by those present at the Bullbar Workshop sponsored by the New South Wales Roads and Traffic Authority and the NRMA, that all parties involved needed to discuss the issues involved to arrive at a workable solution. That is why the Federal Office of Road Safety and the National Road Transport Commission is coordinating a special working group to examine these issues. It is intended that the bullbar industry be represented on this working group where they can present any test results they might have.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 11 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Given that for the 1991-92 financial year, 670 000 bicycles were sold in Australia as opposed to 437 075 new cars, why has the Government withdrawn secretariat support for the National Bicycle Strategy.
(2) Do 3.2 million Australians use bicycles at least once a week.
(3) Has the National Bicycle Strategy been enthusiastically supported by the States.
(4) Are 19 per cent or 7 500 of Australian road crash victims admitted to hospital each year pedal cyclists.
(5) Will full implementation of the National Bicycle Strategy reduce the number of pedal cyclists admitted to hospital each year.
(6) Will a full-time national bicycle secretariat officer be established within the department with appropriate support facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commonwealth recognises the importance of cycling in the overall transport sector and participated actively in the development of a National Bicycle Strategy, which was endorsed by the Australian Transport Advisory Council in October 1992. The issue now is one of implementation, which is a matter for the individual jurisdictions actually delivering initiatives under the Strategy. They will obviously benefit from liaising and sharing experiences from time to time, but the Commonwealth does not consider that a standing committee serviced by it is necessary to achieve this outcome.
This position was outlined at the Australian Transport Council meeting in Adelaide on Friday, 14 October 1994 and was accepted by State and Territory Ministers.
(2) This is the estimate of cycle use prepared by members of the National Bicycle Strategy Committee from Australian Bureau of Statistics Supplementary Surveys carried out in NSW and WA.
(3) Yes.

(4) Yes, this statistic comes from the report `Road crashes resulting in hospitalisation, Australia 1990. Statistical summary, year ended 31 December 1990' issued by the Federal Office of Road Safety in October 1993. That report also shows that pedal cyclists represented 3.4% of road fatalities and 6.3% of road crash hospitalisations (cyclists suffering serious injuries).

(5) All State and Territory jurisdictions have worked to reduce the level of cycling crashes and trauma within their control by cooperating with local government, user groups, and community organisations on such initiatives as:
improving safety by upgrading infrastructure and on-road regulation, including law enforcement;
providing education for cyclists and motorists in order to improve awareness of laws and behaviour relating to cyclists; and
maintaining high standards of construction for bicycles and safety accessories.
The National Bicycle Strategy builds on these initiatives and will therefore contribute to a safer environment for cyclists.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 12 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: In the context of achieving the Government's stated immigration intake for any given year, does the department prepare quotas or targets (informally or formally) for various posts (overseas and/or domestic) to strive to attain for that period; if so, what are the details of the quotas/targets for each post for the 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years, broken down into visa class/category.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: There are no quotas or targets assigned to individual posts or onshore regional offices, but there are stated planning levels at the start of the program year. The progress of the program is closely monitored and if it becomes clear that planning levels are likely to be exceeded, or there will be a considerable shortfall in approvals, close management of places may be undertaken in the Concessional Family and Independent categories through notional allocations to overseas posts. Such allocations are made following close consultations with posts, and are determined solely by such factors as overseas application rates and posts' processing capacities. The allocations are constantly adjusted (often on a week-by-week basis) during the program year as processing trends within posts and regional offices become evident. Management allocations for these two categories do not imply country or regional targets or limits.

Indicative planning levels are set for each Humanitarian processing post for each component, namely Refugees, Special Humanitarian Program (SHP) and Special Assistance Category (SAC). These initial levels can change significantly throughout the program year in response to factors, including the posts' reassessment of the size of their caseload and emerging situations, which require new or changed responses. There is, however, an upper limit for the SACs which is set by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
